Honeywell Salt Lake City





About Honeywell Salt Lake City



Honeywell Salt Lake City is a manufacturing facility of Honeywell Electronic Materials, Inc., located in Salt Lake City, Utah.  It is a member of the Perfomance Materials and Technologies business group of Honeywell International Inc.



Honeywell International Inc. (Honeywell.com) is a Fortune 100 diversified technology and manufacturing leader, serving customers worldwide with aerospace products and services; control technologies for buildings, homes and industry; automotive products; turbochargers; and specialty materials.  Based in Morristown, New Jersey, Honeywell shares are traded on the New York, London, and Chicago Stock Exchanges.  For more news and information on Honeywell, please visit www.honeywellnow.com.



Honeywell Perfomance Materials and Technologies, also based in Morristown, N.J., is a global leader in providing customers with high-performance specialty materials, including fluorine products, specialty films and additives, advanced fibers and composites, intermediate chemicals, specialty chemicals, electronic materials and chemicals, and technologies and materials for petroleum refining.



Health, Safety and Environment/Responsible Care



Honeywell Salt Lake City is committed to managing health, safety and the environment as a core business value to ensure compliance with all applicable government standards and regulations.  Honeywell Salt Lake City also integrates health, safety, and environmental management into our business as a way of achieving profitable growth and accelerated productivity.



Honeywell Perfomance Materials and Technologies participates in the Responsible Care program of the American Chemistry Council, and has achieved and maintained certification to the standard since 2005.  Responsible Care is a chemical industry program focused on achieving improvements in environmental, health and safety performance beyond levels required b

y the U.S. government.



The Responsible Care program directs its companies to adopt practices for the safe use of materials, to perform regular audits, and to reach out and communicate with the communities in which the companies operate. 



Honeywell Salt Lake City



Honeywell Salt Lake City is a primary titanium metal manufacturing facility that has approximately 20 employees.  The plant's products are used primarily to make sputtering targets for the electronics industry and powder metallurgical parts.



One of the materials used by the facility is titanium tetrachloride, which is on the RMP Rule's list of regulated substances.  The Honeywell Salt Lake City plant's storage and use of titanium tetrachloride exceeds the specified threshold 2,500 lbs., as defined by the EPA's RMP Rule.



In accordance with the requirements of the RMP Rule, a description of the following six elements is provided for the Honeywell Salt Lake City plant:



(1)     Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



It is the policy of Honeywell Salt Lake City plant to operate a safe and environmentally sound facility by identifying and controlling health, safety, or environmental risks related to its operations; by designing its processes to protect people, property, and the environment; by conducting and continually reviewing and improving programs for safety, health, and environmental excellence; and by establishing processes to assure that all laws and regulations applicable to its operations and products are known and observed. The accidental release prevention and emergency response policy associated specifically with Honeywell Salt Lake City's use of titanium tetrachloride involves the integration of safety devices and technologies inherent in the design of the processes, safe operational procedures and management practices, operator training, emergency response plans, maintenance of emergency response equipment, coordination with local emergency response services,

and communicating with the community.



(2)    Description of the Facility and the Regulated Substances Handled:



Honeywell Salt Lake City produces high purity titanium.  The manufacturing process includes the utilization of titanium tetrachloride.  Titanium is produced by the reduction of titanium tetrachloride using sodium.  Further processing of the titanium includes crushing, leaching, rinsing, drying, and product sizing.



(3)  The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps: 



Honeywell Salt Lake City pursues a philosophy of continuous improvement in all aspects of its operations. Improvements are identified and implemented throughout the facility's planning and operating cycles.  The employees at Honeywell Salt Lake City are committed to the safe and reliable operation of the plant in a manner that safeguards life, health, property, and the environment.  The process safety and risk management initiatives are implemented as proactive approaches to minimize the potential for accidental releases.  



Honeywell Salt Lake City has evaluated titanium tetrachloride systems based on the EPA's guidelines.  Additionally, the titanium tetrachloride systems were built in accordance with the design code and specification as recommended by a supplier.  The supplier has over 20 years experience in the storage and handling of titanium tetrachloride.  The systems include many built-in safety devices including level alarms, high-level cutouts, safety vents, spare vessels for holding material, and pressure relief devices.  In addition, a foam spray system is installed at the offloading and bulk storage to mitigate fume emission in the event of a release; video cameras are installed to allow remote monitoring, and smoke detectors to allow early detection of a release.

    

Honeywell Salt Lake City has established specific guidelines and procedures for compiling and maintaining written information for the chemical processes we operate.

Specific responsibilities for maintaining this process safety information have been identified and assigned to qualified individuals.  The plant's hazard communication program communicates the health and environmental effects of chemicals to our employees.  We also maintain comprehensive evaluations of the process chemistry and operating conditions of our processes.

    

Each chemical process is analyzed utilizing a method designed to identify, prevent, and minimize the effects of hazards such as a fire, chemical release, process control, and explosions.  The utilization of Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) techniques has been applied at Honeywell Salt Lake City for many years.  The process safety analysis approach is applied to major modifications and also to minor operating changes.  We review the process hazard analyses on a continuing 5-year cycle so that we can maintain the safety of our processes.  Each PHA uses the appropriate methodology to analyze potential hazards and their affects and provides for timely resolution of recommendations.

    

Written operating procedures are structured to cover the significant aspects of plant operation including startup, shutdown, normal operations, upset conditions, and emergency response. Standard operating procedures and checklists are in place and are updated as needed. 



Besides standard operating procedures, Honeywell Salt Lake City has developed training materials to support the development of individuals into trained and qualified process operators.  Operators performing titanium tetrachloride operations must be certified.  Certification is in accordance with established ISO 9000 procedures and includes classroom training, on the job training, a written test, and a demonstration of ability (practical test).

    

Mechanical integrity of plant equipment is another way Honeywell Salt Lake City reduces the probability and consequences of potential releases.  On-going inspection programs are a key part of maintaining the me

chanical integrity of the process equipment.  Safety critical devices and the foam spray system are tested periodically to verify that they function correctly. Certain components are scheduled for periodic replacement, as appropriate.  A schedule is used for physical inspection on the tanks and transfer lines as part of the mechanical integrity program.  Guidelines and procedures have been developed and are followed by people performing the inspections.  Honeywell Salt Lake City personnel are trained and qualified to analyze data and provide operations with timely information for continued safe equipment operation.  Quality assurance of new equipment, processes and spare parts provide additional confidence that the equipment containing the process chemicals will perform as designed.  

    

Honeywell Salt Lake City's contractor safety program encompasses contractor screening for suitability to perform to Honeywell Perfomance Materials and Technologies standards. Contractors working on-site meet the strict safety requirements including: 

-    A comprehensive safety orientation

-    Qualification and training documentation

-    Formal audit system

-    An incident-investigation procedure

 

(4)  Five-Year Accident History:



There have been no accidental releases involving titanium tetrachloride in the last five (5) years.



(5)  Emergency Response Plan:



It is the policy of Honeywell Salt Lake City to operate a safe and environmentally sound facility by identifying and controlling health, safety, and environmental risks related to its operations.  By designing its processes to protect people, property, and the environment and regularly reviewing and improving processes and programs, Honeywell Salt Lake City has an active prevention strategy for its processes. The prevention strategy involves the integration of safety devices and technologies inherent in the design of the process, safe operational procedures, and management practices, operator training, emergency response

planning, maintenance of process and emergency response equipment, coordination of resources and plans with the local and state emergency services, and communication with the community.



The emergency response plan provides for an audible alarm system to alert employees, and for notification of the community through the local police and fire departments as may be appropriate.  Evacuation procedures also are included in the emergency response plan. Honeywell Salt Lake City has agreed with the local emergency response provider that the provider will perform emergency response for the facility.  Honeywell Salt Lake City is incorporated into the local fire department's emergency response program, and Honeywell Salt Lake City has provided the fire department with a copy of the plant's emergency response plan.



(6) Planned Changes to Improve Safety:







Honeywell Salt Lake City strives to continually improve process safety at the site.  Planned changes include wastewater treatment system improvements, noise reduction engineering, ventilation improvements, respiratory protection upgrades and upgrades to our dryer technology.
